full_title_en: Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia
search_abbreviation_en: Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia
medium_description_en: Measures the prevalence of positive and negative syndromes in schizophrenia.

input_schema.name: delusions
input_schema.tips_en: Beliefs which are unfounded, unrealistic, and idiosyncratic

input_schema.name: disorg
input_schema.tips_en: Disorganized process of thinking characterized by disruption of goal-directed sequencing

input_schema.name: hallu
input_schema.tips_en: Verbal report or behavior indicating perceptions which are not generated by external stimuli

input_schema.name: excite
input_schema.tips_en: Hyperactivity as reflected in accelerated motor behavior, heightened responsivity to stimuli, hypervigilance, or excessive mood lability

input_schema.name: grand
input_schema.tips_en: Exaggerated self-opinion and unrealistic convictions of superiority, including delusions of extraordinary abilities, wealth, knowledge, fame, power, and moral righteousness

input_schema.name: sus
input_schema.tips_en: Unrealistic or exaggerated ideas of persecution, as reflected in guardedness, distrustful attitude, suspicious hypervigilance, or frank delusions that others mean harm

input_schema.name: hostility
input_schema.tips_en: Verbal and nonverbal expressions of anger and resentment, including sarcasm, passive-aggressive behavior, verbal abuse, and assaultiveness

input_schema.name: blunt
input_schema.tips_en: Diminished emotional responsiveness as characterized by a reduction in facial expression, modulation of feelings, and communicative gestures

input_schema.name: withdrawal
input_schema.tips_en: Lack of interest in, involvement with, and affective commitment to life’s events

input_schema.name: rapport
input_schema.tips_en: Lack of interpersonal empathy, openness in conversation, and sense of closeness, interest, or involvement with the interviewer

input_schema.name: apathy
input_schema.tips_en: Diminished interest and initiative in social interactions due to passivity, apathy, anergy, or avolition

input_schema.name: abstract
input_schema.tips_en: Impairment in the use of the abstract-symbolic mode of thinking, as evidenced by difficulty in classification, forming generalizations, and proceeding beyond concrete or egocentric thinking in problem-solving tasks

input_schema.name: flow
input_schema.tips_en: Reduction in the normal flow of communication associated with apathy, avolition, defensiveness, or cognitive deficit
input_schema.label_en: Lack of spontaneity and flow of conversation

input_schema.name: stereotype
input_schema.tips_en: Decreased fluidity, spontaneity, and flexibility of thinking, as evidenced in rigid, repetitious, or barren thought content

input_schema.name: concern
input_schema.tips_en: Physical complaints or beliefs about bodily illness or malfunctions

input_schema.name: anxiety
input_schema.tips_en: Subjective experience of nervousness, worry, apprehension, or restlessness, ranging from excessive concern to feelings of panic about the present or future

input_schema.name: guilt
input_schema.tips_en: Sense of remorse or self-blame for real or imagined misdeeds in the past

input_schema.name: tension
input_schema.tips_en: Overt physical manifestations of fear, anxiety, and agitation, such as stiffness, tremor, profuse sweating, and restlessness

input_schema.name: manner
input_schema.tips_en: Unnatural movements or posture as characterized be an awkward, stilted, disorganized, or bizarre appearance

input_schema.name: depression
input_schema.tips_en: Feelings of sadness, discouragement, helplessness, and pessimism

input_schema.name: motor
input_schema.tips_en: Reduction in motor activity as reflected in slowing or lessening of movements and speech, diminished responsiveness of stimuli, and reduced body tone

input_schema.name: uncooperative
input_schema.tips_en: Active refusal to comply with the will of significant others, including the interviewer, hospital staff or family, which may be associated with distrust, defensiveness, stubbornness, negativism, rejection of authority, hostility, or belligerence

input_schema.name: unusual
input_schema.tips_en: Thinking characterized by strange, fantastic, or bizarre ideas, ranging from those which are remote or atypical to those which are distorted, illogical, and patently absurd

input_schema.name: disorientation
input_schema.tips_en: Lack of awareness of one’s relationship to the milieu, including persons, place, and time, which may be due to confusion or withdrawal

input_schema.name: attention
input_schema.tips_en: Failure in focused alertness manifested by poor concentration, distractibility from internal and external stimuli, and difficulty in harnessing, sustaining, or shifting focus to new stimuli

input_schema.name: insight
input_schema.tips_en: Impaired awareness or understanding of one’s own psychiatric condition and life situation

input_schema.name: volition
input_schema.tips_en: Disturbance in the wilful initiation, sustenance, and control of one’s thoughts, behavior, movements, and speech

input_schema.name: impulse
input_schema.tips_en: Disordered regulation and control of action on inner urges, resulting in sudden, unmodulated, arbitrary, or misdirected discharge of tension and emotions without concern about consequences

input_schema.name: preoccupation
input_schema.tips_en: Absorption with internally generated thoughts and feelings and with autistic experiences to the detriment of reality orientation and adaptive behavior

input_schema.name: social
input_schema.tips_en: Diminished social involvement associated with unwarranted fear, hostility, or distrust

how_to_use.use_case_en: Do you use the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

about.formula_en:
The PANSS Score is calculated by the addition of the selected points:

Variable Points
Positive Scale
Delusions Beliefs which are unfounded, unrealistic, and idiosyncratic Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Conceptual disorganization Disorganized process of thinking characterized by disruption of goal-directed sequencing Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Hallucinatory behavior Verbal report or behavior indicating perceptions which are not generated by external stimuli Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Excitement Hyperactivity as reflected in accelerated motor behavior, heightened responsivity to stimuli, hypervigilance, or excessive mood lability Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Grandiosity Exaggerated self-opinion and unrealistic convictions of superiority, including delusions of extraordinary abilities, wealth, knowledge, fame, power, and moral righteousness Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Suspiciousness Unrealistic or exaggerated ideas of persecution, as reflected in guardedness, distrustful attitude, suspicious hypervigilance, or frank delusions that others mean harm Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Hostility Verbal and nonverbal expressions of anger and resentment, including sarcasm, passive-aggressive behavior, verbal abuse, and assaultiveness Absent 1
Minimal 2

Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7

about.more_info_en:
Interpretation:

PANSS Score Schizophrenia Severity
≤57 Not ill
58-74 Mildly ill
75-94 Moderately ill
95-115 Markedly ill
≥116 Severely ill

Validation.text: Levine SZ, Rabinowitz J, Engel R, Etschel E, Leucht S. Extrapolation between measures of symptom severity and change: an examination of the PANSS and CGI. Schizophr Res. 2008;98(1-3):318-322.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Kay SR, Fiszbein A, Opler LA. The positive and negative syndrome scale (Panss) for schizophrenia. Schizophrenia Bulletin. 1987;13(2):261-276.

Other References.text: Leucht S, Kane JM, Kissling W, Hamann J, Etschel E, Engel RR. What does the PANSS mean? Schizophr Res. 2005;79(2-3):231-238.

creator_info.about_en: Stanley R. Kay, PhD, (d. 1990) was a research psychologist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, New York. He was chief of the schizophrenia research program in the Department of Psychiatry at the medical school and director of physiological research at the Bronx Psychiatric Center. Dr. Kay’s primary research focused on schizophrenia with special emphasis on phenomenological and therapeutic studies.

seo.meta_description_en: The Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia measures the prevalence of positive and negative syndromes in schizophrenia.
seo.keywords_en: Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia, panss, panss scale, positive and negative scale, schizophrenia, schizophrenia scale, schizophrenia syndrome scale, positive schizophrenia scale, negative schizophrenia scale, positive syndrome scale, negative syndrome scale
